@optombenno Standard fluid resistant face masks are worn for protection from the transmission of a virus by respiratory droplets, which may be released from the mouth during coughing, sneezing or speaking. Pt.3/3

@optombenno The transmission of COVID-19 is thought to occur mainly through respiratory droplets generated by coughing and sneezing, and through contact with contaminated surfaces. The predominant modes of transmission are assumed to be droplet and contact. Pt.2/3

@optombenno The College is following current Public Health England guidance (2nd April 2020), which recommends that clinicians should wear standard fluid resistant face masks when examining or treating patients at a distance closer than two metres, such as at the slit lamp. Pt.1/3

@eyesoneyecare Hi @eyesoneyecare. That's a really good question. We would be interested in working with manufacturers and other bodies to develop some research in this area. If interested, please contact @PalmerbowenM - Director of Research at the College.
@lizannegregory Part 2 of 2: Without knowing your circumstances we really cannot comment further, so I would ask the practitioner to explain why they are not supplying you with any more lenses.

@lizannegregory Part 1 of 2: According to the Opticians Act (https://t.co/LhpiqXXRUA) it is illegal to supply contact lenses unless the patient has a valid contact lens specification.  How many lenses can be supplied is up to the professional judgement of the supplying practitioner.
@lizannegregory Hi @lizannegregory. We are the professional body for optometry. Your optometrist will be able to advise you whether you can order contact lenses, and if so how many.
